title: Differentiation and single-cell RNA-seq analyses of human pluripotent-stem-cell-derived renal organoids
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Differentiation of kidney organoids
The following protocol is modified from work previously published by Freedman et al.3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3] and Pietrobon et al.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] In this protocol, hPSCs are cultured to high confluence, dissociated, and seeded into a 3D Matrigel culture, resulting in the spontaneous formation of 3D epiblast-like spheroids. Treatment with initiation medium containing GSK3β inhibitor results in differentiation of these spheroids into organized nephron-like structures containing clusters of cells with podocyte, proximal tubule, and distal tubule features.
Timing: 4 to 6 weeks (for mature organoids)
Pluripotent stem cell culture
Timing: 1 to 3 weeks (for steps 1 to 4)
These steps describe the culture and maintenance of hPSCs. We additionally detail cleaning steps used to remove spontaneously differentiated and overgrown hPSC colonies to achieve minimally differentiated hPSC colonies which are ideal for kidney organoid production.
Note: All reagents and vessels for tissue culture must be kept sterile. Work should be performed in a Biological Safety Cabinet (BSC). All surfaces should be disinfected with 70% ethanol before commencing work. All objects should be wiped down with 70% ethanol before being placed in or removed from the BSC.
Note: See Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] for tissue culture vessel well volumes.

Prepare Matrigel-coated plates for hPSC culture.
Thaw Matrigel according to manufacturer’s instructions and dilute to 0.02 mg/mL using cold (4°C) DMEM/F12.
Note: This protocol is optimized using Matrigel Growth Factor Reduced. Refer to key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table].
Critical: Ensure that Matrigel solution is well-mixed. Do not allow Matrigel solution to warm to room temperature or it will prematurely polymerize. Store Matrigel solution on ice if it will not be used immediately.
Dispense half-well volume of Matrigel solution per well.
Note: Matrigel-coated plates may be sealed with parafilm and stored at 4°C for up to 2 weeks.

Incubate Matrigel-coated plates at room temperature for a minimum of 1 h before use.
Thaw and seed hPSCs.
Prepare growth medium (refer to key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table] and materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] sections for detailed recipe).
Warm growth medium in 37°C water bath.
Remove vial of hPSCs from cryogenic storage.
Rapidly thaw hPSCs by swirling the vial gently in a 37°C water bath. Remove vial from water once only a small pellet of ice remains.
Using a wide-bore P1000, transfer contents of vial to 15 mL conical tube containing 5 mL growth medium.
Critical: A wide-bore pipette tip should be used any time hPSC colonies are being pipetted. Excess cell death may occur when using a standard pipette tip due to shear stress.
Pellet hPSCs by centrifugation, 5 min at 250 g. Aspirate supernatant.
Aspirate Matrigel solution from culture vessel and replace with 1x well volume of warmed growth medium.
Resuspend hPSCs in 1 mL growth medium and dispense into Matrigel-coated well.
Transfer plate to hypoxic incubator set to 37°C, 5% O2, 10% CO2.
Refresh growth medium every 48 h.
Note: hPSCs should be inspected for differentiation before refreshing growth medium. Make note of areas of the plate containing healthy hPSC colonies and refer to step 3 for removal of differentiated cells if spontaneous differentiation is moderate or higher. See Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1].
Critical: hPSC colonies should not be cleaned excessively. hPSCs should be cleaned only when there is excessive differentiation. Avoid performing the following step more than once per medium change (48 h) if possible.
Remove differentiated cells by washing if required. Refer to Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1] and 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2] for this step.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2711-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Typical timeline for removal of spontaneously differentiated cells from hPSC maintenance cultures
Scale bars = 500 μm.

(A) Cell dissociation buffer (EDTA) was added to hPSC colonies with moderate differentiation at 0 min. Regions of differentiated cells were sprayed repeatedly using a pipette to remove cells as shown at 2 min. Cell dissociation buffer was replaced with PBS and additional washing was performed until most of the differentiated cells had been washed away at 4 min. The remaining colonies were rinsed gently with fresh PBS to remove non-adherent cells before growth medium was added and the cells were returned to an incubator at 6 min. Lifted edges of hPSC colonies had reattached to the plate at 10 min. Some differentiated cells remain adherent and may be removed during subsequent washes or during passaging.
(B) Removal of overgrown areas from hPSC colony. Cell dissociation buffer was added at 0 min. Overgrown areas were removed by spraying repeatedly with a pipette tip. Cell dissociation buffer was replaced with PBS after 3 min, and washing was continued until overgrown areas were removed.
(C) Typical appearance of hPSC colonies in a 6-well plate as seen by naked eye. Red circles (left panel) indicate regions containing overgrown colonies which should be sprayed with dissociation buffer.
(D) 1) Overgrown colonies are visible as raised bumps when the plate is tiled (red arrowheads). 2) Colonies are washed using dissociation buffer to remove overgrown areas (yellow arrowheads). 3) Colonies appear flattened after removal of overgrown areas. 4) Loosely adherent cells can be removed by running dissociation buffer down the side of each well.
Inspect hPSCs under a microscope.
Inspect the colonies for overgrown regions.

Note: Overgrown regions typically occur at the centers of hPSC colonies. These regions appear to the naked eye as opaque white foci (See Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B and 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C). Any colonies containing overgrown areas should be washed, as these areas may contribute to spontaneous differentiation of the hPSCs.
Identify areas containing moderately or highly spontaneously differentiated hPSC colonies. Refer to Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1].
Note: Differentiated cells typically appear around the edges of colonies and may require magnification to identify. hPSC colonies with low levels of spontaneous differentiation and that are not overgrown do not need to be washed.
Aspirate growth medium and replace with half-well volume of cell dissociation buffer (refer to key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table] and materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] sections for detailed recipe).
Immediately use a pipette to spray the areas containing overgrown and differentiated hPSC colonies with cell dissociation buffer 2 to 3x.
Direct spray at overgrown regions of hPSC colonies to wash away cells.
Note: Spray gently at first and increase force if overgrown areas do not detach. Avoid spraying colonies so forcefully that the entire colony washes away.
Inspect hPSCs under microscope.
If hPSCs have been sufficiently cleaned, proceed to step 3e.
If overgrown or excessively differentiated cells are detaching but still adherent, repeat step 3c.
If overgrown or excessively differentiated cells remain strongly adherent, incubate at room temperature for 30s and inspect again.
Note: Sufficiently detached cells will begin to pull away from neighboring cells. Refer to Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2].
Critical: Incubation with cell dissociation buffer for longer than 5 min may cause excessive detachment of undifferentiated hPSCs. Avoid excessive washing of areas containing undifferentiated hPSC colonies.

Critical: Although longer (> 3 min) incubation times may be required to remove differentiated cells, do not proceed to passaging (step 4) if hPSCs were incubated with cell dissociation buffer for longer than 3 min or the colonies may break up excessively. If hPSCs must be passaged after washing, replace cell dissociation buffer with growth medium and return the cells to an incubator for at least an h before passaging.
Aspirate cell dissociation buffer and rinse gently with PBS to remove loose cells.
Replace with 1x well volume of growth medium and return cells to hypoxic incubator.
Passage hPSC colonies.
Note: Prepare Matrigel-coated plates as described in step 1 before proceeding.
Replace growth medium with half-well volume of cell dissociation buffer.
Perform wash steps as described in step 3 if necessary.
This step removes differentiated and overgrown areas of hPSC colonies
Note: Washing may be omitted if hPSCs are minimally differentiated.
Critical: Incubate hPSCs with cell dissociation buffer for a maximum of 3 min.
Replace cell dissociation buffer with half-well volume of growth medium.
Use cell scraper to gently lift hPSC colonies.
Transfer hPSC colonies to a 15 mL conical tube containing 2 mL growth medium.
Critical: Avoid breaking up hPSC colonies. Scrape hPSCs gently and transfer using wide-bore P1000.
Pellet large hPSC aggregates by centrifugation, 250 g for 10–20 S.
Note: Single cells and small aggregates should remain in suspension.
Aspirate supernatant and resuspend hPSCs in 1 mL growth medium.
Critical: Do not mix excessively to avoid breaking up hPSC colonies. Refer to Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3] for typical size and appearance of hPSC colony fragments following passaging.

Figure 3. hPSCs viewed immediately following passaging (passaged colony fragments are visible)
Scale bar = 500 μm.
Seed hPSC colonies into plates at a split ratio of 1:10 to 1:20.

Note: Cells should reach 70–80% confluence in 3–4 days. Adjust split ratio accordingly to achieve this.
Pause point: hPSCs may be maintained in culture for weeks until ready to proceed to kidney organoid differentiation as long as they are cleaned and passaged regularly to avoid spontaneous differentiation. hPSCs may also be cryopreserved and recovered when needed.
Prime hPSCs for differentiation
Timing: 3 days to 1 week (for steps 5 to 7)
These steps describe how hPSCs are cultured to high confluence with minimal spontaneous differentiation to prepare for kidney organoid differentiation.
Passage hPSCs at a split ratio to achieve 70–80% confluence in 3–4 days. troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Note: Washing steps may be omitted if colonies are minimally differentiated.
Critical: If cells were previously cultured with antibiotics, replace medium with antibiotic-free growth medium from this point on.
Transfer plate to normoxic incubator, 5% CO2, 21% O2.
Inspect cells for differentiation, washing as required, and refresh growth medium every 48 h.
Maintain hPSCs until >70% confluence is reached.
Critical: hPSCs must be at least 70% confluent and be minimally differentiated before proceeding to differentiation. Repeat splitting protocol if excessive differentiation is present. Refer to Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4] as ideal cultures for kidney organoid differentiation.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2711-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. hPSC colonies ready for kidney organoid differentiation
Ideal hPSC colonies should be minimally differentiated and grown to high confluence. Scale bar = 500 μm.
Day 1: Preparation of organoid plates and cell seeding
Timing: 0.5 to 3 h (for steps 8 to 12)
These steps describe preparation of kidney organoid differentiation media and vessels, as well as the dissociation of hPSCs into single cells and seeding in order to produce a monolayer.
Critical: Cells are cultured in normoxic conditions from this point on.

Prepare growth, ROCKi & ABG media. Refer to key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table] and materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] sections for detailed recipe.
Note: ROCKi medium is growth medium supplemented with 10 nM Y27632 ROCK inhibitor to permit survival of dissociated hPSCs during cell seeding. Once initiated, organoids will be maintained in ABG medium until maturity.
For each well containing hPSCs to be differentiated, replace growth medium with half-well volume of ROCKi medium and return to normoxic incubator.
Note: hPSCs should be incubated with ROCKi medium for a minimum of 2 h.
Prepare Matrigel-coated organoid vessels.
Dilute Matrigel to 0.5 mg/mL using cold DMEM/F12.
Dispense half-well volume of Matrigel solution per well.
Critical: Matrigel solution must be kept cold while working. Ensure that Matrigel solution is well-mixed.
Note: Matrigel-coated plates may be sealed with parafilm and stored at 4°C for up to 2 weeks.
Note: Differentiation can be performed in a range of vessel sizes, however smaller vessels, such as 96-well plates, are typically most efficient and allow for optimization of a large number of conditions.
Incubate at room temperature for a minimum of 1h before use.
Dissociate hPSCs.
Critical: hPSCs must be minimally differentiated before proceeding.
Gently wash away overgrown areas of hPSC colonies, if necessary, by spraying with the ROCKi medium in each well.
Aspirate wells and gently rinse with PBS to remove loose cells.
Aspirate wells, add half-well volume of Accutase to each well and return cells to normoxic incubator for 10 min.
Tap side of plate and inspect cells. Return cells to incubator for an additional 5 min if colonies are not completely dissociated into single cells.
Transfer dissociated hPSCs to 15 mL conical tube.
Rinse wells with ROCKi medium and add to tube.
Note: Rinse with 2 mL ROCKi medium for each 1 mL Accutase.

Pellet cells by centrifugation, 250 g for 5 min.
Count and seed cells.
Aspirate supernatant and resuspend cells in 1 mL ROCKi medium using wide-bore P1000.
Critical: Avoid excessive mixing.
Count cells and adjust volume to 1 × 106 cells/mL.
Aspirate Matrigel solution from organoid vessel and replace with 1x well volume ROCKi medium.
Seed cells at desired density.
Note: Seeding density should be optimized for each cell line. Typical seeding densities range from 1000 to 3 × 104 cells/cm2. We recommend testing at 1500, 3000, 4500, 6000, 1 × 104, 1.5 × 104, 2 × 104, and 2.5 × 104 cells/cm2 to find the ideal seeding density for your hPSC line of interest. We typically seed H9 embryonic stem cells at 4500 to 5000 cells/cm2, and D168 induced pluripotent stem cells at 14,000 to 19,000 cells/cm2.
Rock plate gently to disperse cells and return plate to normoxic incubator overnight (12–24 h).
Note: Cells should be well adherent before proceeding.
Day 2: Overlay cells with Matrigel
Timing: 0.5 to 1 h (for step 13)
This step describes overlaying of the hPSC monolayer generated in the previous step with Matrigel in order to produce epiblast-like spheroids.
Overlay cells with Matrigel.
Dilute Matrigel to 0.25 mg/mL with cold growth medium.
Critical: Matrigel must be diluted with cold growth medium to prevent premature polymerization.
Aspirate medium from organoid plate and replace with 1x well volume cold Matrigel solution.
Note: Do not warm Matrigel solution. Matrigel solution is added to cells while cold.
Return plates to incubator until day 4.
Note: It is not necessary to replace the Matrigel/growth medium solution the next day if it is not depleted, as indicated by a change in color to yellow or orange. Replace with fresh growth medium only if necessary.
Day 4: Initiate differentiation

Timing: 0.5 to 1 h (for step 14)
This step describes treatment of the epiblast-like spheroids produced in the previous step with a GSK3β inhibitor to initiate their differentiation into kidney organoids.
Note: Cells should start to form epiblast-like spheroids following incubation. Refer to Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]. troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2711-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Typical progression of hPSCs during differentiation
Day 3: Hollow epiblast-like spheroids formed by hPSCs overlayed with Matrigel. Day 5: Treatment with CHIR-99021 results in dissociation of spheroids. Day 7: Cells recovering and forming large aggregates after transition to ABG medium. Days 13–21: Formation of mature kidney organoids. Scale bar = 200 μm.
Prepare initiation medium & treat cells. Refer to key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table] and materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] sections for detailed recipe.
Note: Initiation medium contains the GSK3β inhibitor CHIR-99021. CHIR-99021 concentration should be optimized for each cell line. We recommend attempting differentiation using concentrations from 8 to 24 μM to find the optimal conditions for your hPSC line of interest. We typically differentiate H9 embryonic stem cells using 8–12 μM, and D168 induced pluripotent stem cells at 20–24 μM CHIR-99021.
Aspirate Matrigel solution from organoid plate and replace with 2x well volume initiation medium.
Return cells to incubator for 36–42 h. troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]. troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Day 6–21: Maintenance of kidney organoids
Timing: 0.5 to 1 h (for steps 15 to 18)
These steps describe the timing requirements for removal of the initiation medium used in the previous steps and describes how the differentiating kidney organoids should be maintained.
Critical: This step must be performed 36–42 h after addition of initiation medium.
Note: Different incubation lengths with initiation medium will affect the optimal cell density and CHIR-99021 concentration. Maintain a consistent incubation length whenever possible.

Aspirate initiation medium and replace with 2x well volume ABG medium, then return plates to incubator.
Aspirate all ABG medium from the wells after 48 h and refresh with 1x well volume ABG medium.
Refresh with 1x well volume ABG medium every 48–72 h.
Note: If differentiating cells in a vessel larger than a 96-well plate, it is recommended to perform half-medium changes. Differentiation efficiency may be reduced if full-medium changes are performed.
Note: Daily medium changes may be required for high seeding densities.
Tubular structures should become visible between days 12 and 18. See Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]. troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Kidney organoids are fully formed on day 21. troubleshooting 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Note: To validate successful kidney organoid differentiation, see section “Optional: Validation of kidney organoid differentiation by immunofluorescence.”
Pause point: Kidney organoids may be maintained in ABG medium for an additional 1–2 weeks.
Day 21+: Single cell RNA-seq analysis
The MULTI-seq protocol2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2] is employed in the following steps to increase the number of samples analyzed by scRNA-seq without dramatically increasing costs. This method adds a barcoding step to cells while in culture, allowing pooling of multiple samples on the same sequencing run. This methodology also reduces batch technical variation between samples and provides additional quality control processing tools such as true doublet identification. A particularly powerful approach is to analyze samples at multiple different time points.
Total time: 1–2 h for sample prep, 1 + h for analysis.

Note: The following protocol is designed to label 0.5 × 106 live cells for each sample. Thus, we recommend differentiation of organoids in a large enough vessel to ensure a sufficient number of cells. Typically, a well area of 3.8 cm2, or one well of a 12-well plate, is sufficient for each sample. Organoids from multiple smaller wells may be pooled if differentiation is more efficient in other vessel sizes.
Critical: MULTI-seq requires samples to all be processed at the same time, this requires staggered start times of the differentiation protocol so that all desired time points are completed at once.
MULTI-seq sample preparation
Timing: 1 to 2 h (for steps 19 to 24)
These steps describe tagging of cells from dissociated kidney organoids using lipid-modified oligonucleotide (LMO) anchors and unique barcoding oligonucleotides as required for MULTI-seq.
Note: Grow organoids to the desired time points before proceeding (Steps 1 to 18). Kidney organoids should be healthy and high quality before beginning. See Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] for examples of mature kidney organoid quality.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2711-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. A variety of kidney organoids organized by size and complexity
Scale bar = 200 μm. Highest quality organoids suitable for RNA-seq should be relatively large and contain well developed 3D structures, similar to those shown in the rightmost two columns.
Critical: Solutions used in this section must cooled and kept on ice before proceeding. Ensure centrifuge is pre-cooled before proceeding.
Prepare 25 μL of unique 10x barcoding solution and 25 μL of 10x co-anchor solution per sample to be barcoded.
Mix the anchor LMO and barcode stock solutions at a 1:1 M ratio in PBS to a final concentration of 2 μM.
Note: Refer to key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table] and materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] sections for detailed recipe.

Note: While the same anchor strand is used for all samples, a different barcode strand needs to be used for each sample, and hence, a different barcoding solution needs to be mixed for each sample.
Create 10x co-anchor solution by diluting the co-anchor LMO stock solution in PBS to achieve a final concentration of 2 μM.
Note: Prepare 25 μL per sample. Refer to key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table] and materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] sections for detailed recipe.
Note: The same co-anchor solution is used for all samples, so only one solution needs to be mixed.
Prepare 1% BSA in PBS.
Dissociate kidney organoids from each time point.
Note: Samples from each time point should be processed simultaneously.
For each sample, aspirate ABG medium from well containing kidney organoids and gently rinse with 1x well volume of PBS.
Aspirate PBS and add 1x well volume of Accutase.
Return organoids to incubator (37°C) for 15 min.
Use 25g needle and syringe to triturate kidney organoids 3 times.
Note: For large vessel sizes, a cell scraper may be used to break up kidney organoids before trituration with a needle.
Critical: Trituration is required to ensure organoids are disaggregated into single cells. However, to maintain high viability, excessive rough trituration should be avoided.
Transfer each dissociated sample into an individual labeled tube containing 5x well volume of cold PBS.
Critical: Samples must be kept on ice from this point on to minimize expression changes from processing.
Pellet samples by centrifugation at 250 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Aspirate supernatant and resuspend cell pellet in a small volume (approximately 125 μL) of cold PBS.
Note: Concentration of cell suspension should be at least 3 × 106 cells/mL at this point.
Determine cell viability of each sample.

For each sample, aliquot 10 μL of cell suspension in microcentrifuge tube and combine with 10 μL 0.4% Trypan Blue solution. Count cells and determine sample viability.
Adjust concentration of sample cell suspension to 2.8 × 106 cells/mL using cold PBS.
Label each sample with a unique barcode.
For each sample, transfer 0.5 × 106 live cells to a labeled microfuge tube and adjust sample volume to 180 μL with cold PBS.
Add 20 μL of 10x Barcoding solution to each sample and pipette gently to mix. Incubate on ice for 5 min.
Critical: A unique barcoding solution must be prepared for each sample. Ensure that sample and barcode pairs are recorded for future analysis.
Add 22.2 μL of 10x Co-Anchor solution and pipette gently to mix. Incubate on ice for 5–10 min.
Note: Co-Anchor solution is common to all samples.
Add 900 μL of cold 1% BSA solution to each sample and centrifuge at 250 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Use a pipette to remove 1050 μL of supernatant.
Critical: The initial volume of each sample is 1100 μL at this step. 50 μL of liquid and cell pellet should remain in each tube. Do not disturb cell pellet.
Repeat step d, then use a pipette to remove 870 μL supernatant to remove unbound barcodes in solution.
Note: The initial volume of each sample is 950 μL at this step. 80 μL of liquid and cell pellet should remain in each tube.
Triturate the remaining solution with a wide bore p200 to resuspend cells, then determine cell count and viability as in step 21a. troubleshooting 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Critical: Samples must be at least 80% viable at this stage. Do not proceed if fewer than 80% of cells are viable.
Pool barcoded samples.

Combine 2 × 104 cells from each barcoded cell suspension in a single tube.
Adjust cell concentration of combined samples with cold 1% BSA solution to 1000 cells/μL.
Filter pooled and barcoded cell suspension through a 35 μm mesh cell strainer twice.
Submit pooled and barcoded cell suspension for library preparation and RNA sequencing.
Note: This step is often performed by a core facility. Refer to facility guidelines for sample submission. We recommend sequencing to a depth of at least 25,000 reads/cell, however, more or less sequencing depth may be requiring depending on your application.
Processing of scRNA-seq data
Timing: 1+ h (for steps 25 to 37)
These steps describe processing and analysis of the scRNA-seq data obtained following MULTI-seq in order to identify the cell populations present in the combined samples.
Convert Illumina BCL files to FASTQ files
Use the mkfastq function in CellRanger (10X Genomics) software to generate FASTQ files.
Generate raw count matrices with the count function.
Note: This step may not be necessary if your sequencing facility provides you with FASTQ files.
Demultiplex samples using the standard MULTI-seq workflow.2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]
Import data into R, using the Seurat 4.0 package and protocol published by Hao et al.4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]
Note: Most of the subsequent downstream analyses are performed using Seurat and other packages in R.
Plot smoothed density frequencies or histograms of cell quality control metrics such as UMI counts, number of uniquely detected genes, and fraction of mitochondrial reads.
Visually inspect the control metrics and select cut-off thresholds based on the skew of the distributions.
Note: Cells falling outside the designated thresholds are removed from subsequent analyses. See Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7] for examples of appropriate thresholding.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2711-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Example of threshold setting on quality control metrics of scRNA-seq data

Smooth density estimates of cell frequency for (A) number of unique molecular identifiers (nUMI), (B) number of unique genes with detectable reads (nGene), and (C) percentage of reads mapping to mitochondrial genes (PercMito). Thresholds are chosen by visual assessment of the skew of the distribution, with a general tendency towards more permissive thresholds. Cells below the nUMI and nGene thresholds (shaded in yellow) possess too few reads (for nUMI) or uniquely detectable genes (for nGene) to be meaningfully analyzed, and thus, are removed from downstream analysis. Cells above the PercMito threshold (shaded in yellow) are likely apoptotic and are also removed from downstream analysis.
Note: In general, we encourage less stringent thresholds to avoid discarding cells that may possess altered quality control metrics due to a biologically significant cause. For example, cells with a vastly higher number of fractional mitochondrial reads are more likely to be apoptotic cells and can be discarded. However, some metabolically active cell populations, (e.g., hPSCs), contain a slightly higher proportion of mitochondrial transcripts compared to less metabolically active cells (e.g., differentiated cell types). Thus, do not use an overly stringent threshold for discarding cells based on fractional mitochondrial reads.
Remove any cells that were labeled “doublets” or “negatives” by the MULTI-seq analysis pipeline performed in step 26.
Normalize expression using the SCTransform function in Seurat.
Include a regression variable for the difference in cell cycle score between proliferating and non-proliferating cells.
Note: This cell cycle score, which predicts the cycle phase of each cell (G1, G2/M, S), may be determined using the CellCycleScoring function in Seurat.
Perform Principal Components Analysis (PCA) and generate a Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP).
Run the RunPCA function in Seurat.

Run the RunUMAP function on the 40 most variable PCA dimensions to create a Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP).
Critical: This processing generates the reduced dimensionality data which can be employed for clustering and annotation. If you intend to subset your data (e.g., to focus on specific populations), we recommend you recalculate the PCA and UMAP for the selected cells for better cluster-specific visualization.
Cell clustering and annotation
Cluster cells in Seurat.
Use the FindNeighbors function with the top 40 PCA dimensions.
Then use the FindClusters function at a specific resolution parameter.
Critical: The number and size of clusters generated is heavily dependent on the value of the resolution parameter (high values means more clusters with fewer cells in each). In general, there is no universal parameter that can be used and the choice highly depends on the structure of the particular dataset. We recommend empirically testing a variety of resolution parameters and assessing fit based on a priori knowledge of the expected data set. Generally, we begin by selecting a more granular resolution (i.e., more clusters), and then merge clusters that are not distinguished by any biologically recognizable suite of unique markers genes. After clustering at a more granular resolution, we also recommend aggregating clusters into more global groups for analysis. Analyzing your data at two resolutions facilitates inference of biological insights of specific subpopulations, as well as those common to larger groups of cells.
Note: Refer to Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8] for examples of granular and merged clustering based on our published data.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2711-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. Cluster analysis of cell populations derived from kidney organoids

UMAP two-dimensional plots showing (A) granular cluster resolution and (B) aggregated clusters, on 27,828 cells from scRNA-seq data reported in Pietrobon et al., 2022.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] Granular clusters are helpful for identifying changes in specific lineages (e.g., TSC1−/− and TSC2−/− organoids specifically upregulate melanocytic markers in the glial cluster, as reported in Pietrobon et al., 20221[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]). In contrast, aggregated clusters allow inferences of global population changes (e.g., TSC1−/− and TSC2−/− organoids favor stromal cell fate acquisition, as reported in Pietrobon et al. 20221[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]).
Determine uniquely and highly expressed genes in each cluster.
Run the FindAllMarkers function in Seurat.
Visualize the top marker genes in each cluster (generally ranked by p-value) and annotate in one of two ways:
Based on a priori biological knowledge.
Based on comparison to markers from other reported studies.
Note: We used published datasets5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5],6[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6],7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7],8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8],9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9] to annotate kidney organoid clusters. Note: There are more advanced methods for annotating datasets that use previously annotated reference scRNA-seq dataset in a statistically rigorous fashion. However, at this time, there are no gold standard scRNA-seq datasets that exist for renal organoids. Furthermore, results are likely to be variable depending on the differentiation protocol used and timing of extraction.
Trajectory analysis
Infer cell differentiation trajectory using the learn_graph function in monocle3.
Assign a pseudotime value to each cell by using the order_cells function in monocle3 and select the root node (generally the earliest differentiation timepoint).
Perform trajectory analysis with the tradeSeq package.10[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]
Extract the expression and pseudotime values for each cell.
Determine the optimal number of knots empirically using the evaluateK function.

Critical: The optimal number of knots is dataset-dependent. In general, the number of knots selected should reach an optimal bias-variance trade-off, where one explains as much variability in the expression data as possible with only a few regression coefficients. Through evaluateK, the average Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) is calculated across a subset of genes at a range of knots. We recommend choosing the smallest number of knots that reasonably minimizes the average AIC. In general, the optimal number of knots is at the “knee” of the AIC vs number of knots plot.
Note: Refer to Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9] for examples of knot selection.

Fit a Generalized Additive Model using the fitGAM function using the number of knots determined in Step 37b.
Use the associationTest function to find genes that vary significantly along the expression trajectory.

Timing: 2 to 6 months (for steps 38 to 41)
Differential gene expression can be performed between specific groups using the FindMarkers function in Seurat.
Phylogenetic analyses can be conducted using the BuildClusterTree in Seurat.
GO term enrichment can be performed using the clusterProfiler package.
Compositional analysis can be performed using the imbalance_score function from the bioc2020trajectories package.
Optional: Development of genome engineered clonal hPSC lines using CRISPR/Cas9.

Our genome engineering strategy involves the use the CRISPR/Cas9-mediated insertion of a knockout template (i.e., single-stranded oligodeoxynucleotide, ssODN) via homology-directed repair (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]). The knockout template contains stop codons in all three reading frames and a PmeI restriction site which can be harnessed for clone screening, as described below. Although homology-directed repair is a less efficient process compared to non-homologous end joining, we prefer this strategy over non-homologous end joining as it guarantees the generation of a specific sequence which can be reproduced in multiple parental cell lines, thereby ensuring line-specific differences are not secondary to the mutation introduced. We have previously used this approach to generate the same TSC1-null and TSC2-null mutations across four different parental hPSC lines, enabling the direct comparison of the effects of these mutations across multiple genotypes.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1],11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11] A similar homology-directed repair approach may also be used to generate isogenic controls for patient-derived samples by correcting disease-causing mutations.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2711-Fig10.jpg
Figure 10. Overview of the genome engineering strategy used to generate TSC1-null hPSC cell lines
(A) The CRISPR-CAS9 complex and ssDNA repair template are delivered into hPSCs via transfection. The transfected hPSCs are then cultured to form colonies, which are selected and screened for the gene edit.
(B) A double-stranded DNA break is introduced into the first exon shared across all TSC1 splice variants by CRISPR-CAS9. An ssDNA repair template, critically containing stop codons in all reading frames along with a PmeI cut site, is used for homology directed repair of the DNA break. This results in the knockout of the target gene and insertion of a PmeI cut site, used for subsequent screening in successfully edited cells.

There are numerous tools and protocols available for designing and cloning CRISPR/Cas9 plasmids. We used the lentiCRISPRv2 system12[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12] so that the same backbone can be potentially used for screening. We recommend designing multiple plasmids with different guide strands, testing all guides, and selecting the guide with the highest cutting efficiency. For repair template design, we used a sequence previously reported by Gagnon et al.13[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib13] which can be directly ordered from any synthesis company. We describe the below the process of using these tools for genome engineering hPSCs, which is quite different from editing an immortalized cell line.
Prime hPSC cultures
Timing: 1 to 3 weeks (for steps 42)
This step describes the culture conditions and maintenance used to prepare hPSCs for transfection.
Critical: Do not use antibiotics in media. Ensure all plates used are pre-coated with Matrigel or equivalent.
Culture hPSCs as described in steps 1 to 4.
Note: hPSCs should be highly undifferentiated and grown to approximately 80% confluence before proceeding. Clean and passage hPSCs as detailed previously to achieve these conditions.
Note: If hPSCs were maintained in hypoxia up to this point, they should be acclimated to normoxia for 48–72 h before proceeding.
Day 1: Seed hPSC cells for transfection
Timing: 2 to 3 h (for steps 43 to 45)
These steps describe dissociation and seeding of hPSCs into a monolayer the day before transfection.
Critical: Prepare Matrigel-coated plates before dissociating hPSC colonies.
Note: We recommend seeding dissociated hPSCs into 60 mm plates for transfection for ease of colony picking.
Note: hPSCs are maintained in normoxic conditions in the following steps.
Dissociate hPSC colonies into single cells and pellet as described in step 11.
Critical: hPSCs must be incubated with ROCKi medium for a minimum 2 h before dissociation.
Resuspend and count cells as described in step 12.

Seed cell suspension into Matrigel-coated plates containing 1x well volume ROCKi medium at the following concentrations: 2 × 104, 1 × 104, 0.5 × 104, and 0.025 × 104 cells/cm2.
Note: hPSCs are seeded at multiple densities to account for variability in subsequent transfection efficiency and selection steps.
Day 2: Transfection with CRISPR complexes
Timing: 0.5 to 2 h (for steps 46 to 48)
These steps describe the transfection conditions used to deliver CRISPR complexes to the hPSC monolayer generated in the previous section, as well as maintenance and selection of transfected cells.
Note: The following steps are performed 16–24h after seeding dissociated hPSCs.
Aspirate ROCKi medium from plates and replace with 1x well volume growth medium.
Prepare transfection medium:
Note: Volumes below are for a single 60 mm plate.
Tube 1: 100 μL Opti-MEM I medium + 4 μL Lipofectamine Stem Reagent
Tube 2: 100 μL Opti-MEM I medium + 2 μg CRISPR plasmid + 0.5 μL of ssODN (100 μM).
Transfer the contents of tube 2 into tube 1 and mix by gently pipetting.
Incubate transfection medium for 10 min at room temperature.
Add 200 μL of transfection medium dropwise to each plate of cells.
Distribute drops of transfection medium evenly over entire plate, and rock plate gently to ensure even distribution of the transfection complex across the entire plate.
Return cells to incubator overnight.
Aspirate transfection mix and replace with 1x well volume of fresh growth medium. Refresh growth medium daily until ready for colony picking.
Note: hPSCs may be returned to hypoxic conditions 4–5 days after transfection.

Note: If an antibiotic resistance gene, e.g., puromycin, is included in the CRISPR plasmid, then antibiotic selection may be performed during this step. The concentration of antibiotic must be optimized for each hPSC line, and selection may not be possible for cell lines that are particularly sensitive.
Note: Transfected hPSCs should ideally form discrete colonies that do not contact with neighboring colonies. See Figure 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11] for colonies ready for picking.

Scale bar = 500 μm.
Day 19: Colony picking
Timing: 2 to 3 h (for steps 49 to 56)
These steps describe the isolation and transfer of transfected hPSC colonies from the transfection vessel into individual wells of a 96-well plate to facilitate screening.
Note: Multiple plates with cells at different seeding densities were transfected in the above steps, however the optimal plate to select for colony picking is generally the one that took longest to form colonies, and therefore most likely contains clonal colonies.
Prepare Matrigel-coated 96-well plate as described in step 1.
Aspirate media from transfected hPSCs and replace with 2x well volume ROCKi medium.
Return plate to hypoxic incubator for 1 h.
Aspirate Matrigel solution from 96-well plate and replace with 1x well volume ROCKi medium.
Using a p200 pipette, gently scrape off unique colonies and transfer each colony into a well of the 96-well plate. Repeat until the desired number of colonies have been picked. Use a fresh pipette tip for each colony to avoid cross contamination.
Note: We find it helpful to perform this step with a sterile stereoscope. The ideal colony size to pick is roughly 2 to 3x the diameter of the p200 pipette tip. We recommend collecting at least one 96-well plate of colonies.

Critical: Try to minimize volume of ROCKi medium transferred into the 96-well plate along with the selected colony to avoid cross contamination of colonies with floating cells. It may be necessary to refresh the ROCKi medium if excessive numbers of floating cells are present, as these may interfere with clonal selection.
Return 96-well plate containing picked colonies to hypoxic incubator overnight.
Aspirate ROCKi medium and replace with 1x well volume of growth medium.
Critical: Avoid cross contamination of cells between wells.
Refresh growth medium daily until wells reach approximately 80% confluence.
Day 23: Passaging colonies
Timing: 2 to 3 h (for steps 57 to 61)
These steps describe how to passage the selected hPSC colonies and a portion of each colony is collected for DNA extraction and screening.
Note: Prepare Matrigel-coated 96-well plates before proceeding. The following steps additionally require 96-well PCR plates for genotyping of hPSC colonies.
Aspirate growth medium and replace with 30 μL Accutase. Return colonies to incubator for 5 min.
Note: If concerned about viability, colonies may be incubated with ROCKi medium for 2 h before addition of Accutase.
Aspirate Matrigel solution from 96-well plate and replace with 1x well volume ROCKi medium.
Remove colonies from incubator and gently aspirate off cell dissociation buffer. Slowly add 120 μL ROCKi medium to each well.
Critical: Avoid aspirating hPSC colonies.
Use a p200 to scrape and lift hPSC colonies, then gently triturate colonies by pipetting.
Transfer 40 μL into the new Matrigel-coated plate and 40 μL into the PCR plate.
Note: Triturate colonies until they have lifted from the plate but remain as small aggregates.
Critical: Colonies break apart easily at this stage. Avoid vigorous trituration into a single cell suspension.

Return passaged hPSC colonies to hypoxic incubator and immediately proceed to extraction of genomic DNA from PCR plate.
Replace ROCKi medium with growth medium the next day.
Refresh growth medium daily.
Note: We recommend screening clones immediately, as described below, to avoid the need for additional passaging.
Day 23: Extract genomic DNA from colonies
Timing: 0.5 to 1 h (for steps 62 to 63)
These steps describe how DNA is extracted from the hPSC colonies collected in the previous section.
Note: The following steps are performed on the PCR plate containing cell suspension obtained in step 60.
Pellet cell suspension by centrifugation, 600 g for 5 min, and remove supernatant.
Extract DNA using QuickExtract DNA solution:
Add 5 μL of QuickExtract DNA solution to each well.
Seal plate with film, and vortex to mix (15 S) and pool liquid by centrifugation, 500 g for 15 S.
Incubate at 65°C for 6 min using thermal cycler.
Vortex plate, and pool liquid by centrifugation.
Incubate at 98°C for 2 min.
Vortex plate, and pool liquid by centrifugation.
Add 5 μL of PCR-grade H2O.
Vortex plate, and pool liquid by centrifugation.
Note: Use extracted DNA immediately for PCR. Typically 1–2 μL suffices for a 12–25 μL reaction.
Pause point: DNA may be stored at −20°C until ready to proceed.

Perform PCR to screen for clones. Add 18 μL of PCR master mix to each well of a 96-well PCR plate.
Transfer 2 μL of template DNA (obtained in steps 62 to 63) into each well.
Cover the plate with a PCR-compatible seal.
Vortex briefly, then centrifuge to pool liquid, 100 g for 30 S.
Place plate in a thermocycler and perform PCR at the following conditions:

Timing: 1 to 2 days (for steps 76 to 82)
These steps describe how the PCR product obtained in the previous steps is digested using PmeI restriction enzyme, and how gel electrophoresis is used to separate and visualize the PCR products in order to identify successfully edited hPSC colonies.
Prepare a Digestion master mix solution (Table 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl4]).

Digest PCR reaction product.
Add 10 μL of master mix to each well of a PCR-compatible 96-well plate using a multichannel pipette.
Transfer 5 μL from each well of the PCR-amplified reaction product (obtained in step 68).
Seal plate with film.
Vortex briefly, then centrifuge to pool liquid, 100 g for 30 S.
Incubate plate in a thermocycler at 37°C for 1 h.

Note: TBE buffer is preferred here, as a long duration of electrophoresis will be required and TBE is less likely to heat up and melt the gel.

Add 3 μL of 6x loading dye to each well of the digested PCR product.
Load 10 μL of each sample with loading dye into a well of the agarose gel. For each row, add a DNA ladder in the first and last wells.
Perform gel electrophoresis at approximately 100 V. Depending on your fragment size this may take 1–2 h to adequately separate. If the buffer begins to heat up, perform electrophoresis at a lower voltage.
Visualize the gel using a UV transilluminator.
Look for lanes that show two bands.

Optional: Validation of kidney organoid differentiation by immunofluorescence
This section describes staining of kidney organoids for podocyte, proximal tubule and distal tubule markers to visualize structure and organization. It is useful to perform these steps when optimizing the kidney organoid differentiation for your cell lines of choice to ensure that your conditions are producing high quality organoids.
Note: The following protocol is for whole mount imaging, where kidney organoids are fixed, stained and imaged directly in the differentiation vessel. For best image quality, kidney organoids should be differentiated in optical-bottom plates.
Fix kidney organoids.
Add 1x well volume 8% (v/v) formaldehyde solution to differentiation vessel.
Note: It is not necessary to aspirate medium from the vessel before fixation. Final concentration of formaldehyde is 4% v/v.
Incubate at room temperature for 45 min.
Aspirate fixation solution and replace with 2x well volume PBS.
Incubate at room temperature 15 min.
Repeat washing (steps 76c-d) a total of 5 times to remove excess formaldehyde.
Note: Fixed organoids can be stored in PBS + 0.05% NaN3 at 4°C for several weeks.
Pause point: Fixed organoids may be stored at 4°C for several days if necessary.
Permeabilize and block fixed organoids.
Aspirate liquid from wells and replace with permeabilization + block solution (1% BSA, 0.1% TWEEN-20 in PBS).
Incubate at room temperature for 3 h.
Aspirate permeabilization solution and replace with block + wash solution (1% BSA, 0.01% TWEEN-20 in PBS).
Incubate at room temperature for 15 min.
Repeat step 77c-d a total of 3 times.
Stain organoids with primary antibodies. Refer to key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table] for validated antibodies.
Dilute primary antibodies in block + wash solution:

Podocyte marker (NPHS1, 1:100).
Proximal tubule marker (LRP2, 1:100).
Distal tubule marker (CDH1, 1:200).
Note: Prepare a half-well volume of primary antibody solution for each well to be stained.
Aspirate block + wash solution and replace with half-well volume of primary antibody solution.
Incubate at 4°C overnight.
Wash organoids to remove excess antibody.
Aspirate antibody solution and replace with 2x well volume block + wash solution.
Immediately aspirate block + wash solution and replace with 2x well volume fresh block + wash solution. Repeat 3 times.
Aspirate block + wash solution and replace with 2x well volume fresh block + wash solution.
Incubate at room temperature 2 h.
Repeat step 79 c-d a total of 4x over a period of 8 h.
Stain organoids with appropriate fluorescently-tagged secondary antibodies.
Dilute secondary antibodies (1:400) in block + wash solution.
Aspirate block + wash solution and replace with half-well volume secondary antibody solution.
Incubate at 4°C overnight.
Repeat step 79 to remove excess antibody.
Note: Hoechst 33343 (1:1000) may be added to block + wash solution if desired. If so, perform 1 to 2 extra washes (step 79 c-d) to remove excess Hoechst after staining.
Note: If kidney organoids were stained in optical-bottom plates, proceed directly to imaging. Otherwise, mount organoids under coverslips prior to imaging.
Image kidney organoids using fluorescence or confocal microscopy. Well-differentiated kidney organoids should show staining of discrete regions that correspond to human nephron patterning (Figure 13[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig13]).
